book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text:
Introduction
Praise be to Allah as He deserves to be praised, and peace and blessings be upon the most honorable of His prophets and messengers, and the best of His creation, Muhammad bin Abdullah, and upon his family and companions and those who support him.
To proceed...
Indeed, one of the most famous upon whom chains of narration revolve, and from whom reports are narrated, and his Hadith spread in the cities and regions, and the determinations of the narrators of Hadith and its men called upon each other to take from him: The Great Imam Al-Hafiz Muhammad bin Muslim bin Shihab Al-Zuhri (d. 124 AH) may Allah have mercy on him. About whom Ibn Hibban (d. 354 AH) said: "He was the best memorizer among the people of his time for the Sunnahs, and the best of them in context for them" (1). He is among those upon whom the pivot of Hadith was in his time, such that the critic Imam Ali bin Al-Madini (d. 234 AH) began by mentioning him in the first letter of his book, saying: "I looked and found...
foot_note: 1. Mashahir Ulama al-Amsar by Ibn Hibban (444).

text: ...the chain of transmission revolves around six: For the people of Medina: Ibn Shihab; who is Muhammad bin Muslim bin Abdullah bin Shihab...) (1). He had the upper hand in the initial stages characterized by comprehensiveness for collecting reports and recording them, and their spreading and dispersal in the countries and regions, and the great ones followed in narration and taking from him. One of the most trustworthy narrators from him, the most established, and the most majestic: The Star of Sunnahs, the Repository of Sciences, and the Imam of the Abode of Migration; Imam Malik bin Anas (d. 179 AH) may Allah have mercy on him. He is in the first layer of his companions and those taking from him, and the masses of critics stated that he is the most established of those who narrate from Al-Zuhri (2).
foot_note:
1. 'Ilal al-Hadith by Ali bin Al-Madini (86).
2. The masses of critics prioritized him over the companions of Al-Zuhri: Yahya bin Ismail Al-Wasiti said: I heard Yahya bin Saeed Al-Qattan (d. 198 AH) mention the companions of Al-Zuhri one day, and he started with Malik among the first of them... And Abdullah bin Ahmad said: I said to him (meaning: his father): Which of the companions of Al-Zuhri is most established? He said: (Each one of them has a defect, except that Yunus and Uqayl convey the wordings, and Shu'aib bin Abi Hamza, and they are not like Ma'mar, Ma'mar approaches them in the chain). I said: What about Malik? He said: (Malik is most established in everything...) End quote. And according to Ibn Hani: It was said to him: Which of the companions of Al-Zuhri is most beloved to you? He said: (Malik is most beloved to me due to the scarcity of his narration, and after him Ma'mar...), and Abu Talib said: Abu Abdullah said: (And Malik is more established in the Hadith of Al-Zuhri than all who narrated from him). And Yahya bin Ma'in (d. 233 AH) said - following his listing of Al-Zuhri's companions -: (That is the highest of them), and he said: (Malik is the greatest of all people in Al-Zuhri and the most established among them in my view). And Amr Al-Fallas (d. 249 AH) said: (The most established who narrated from Al-Zuhri among those who do not differ from him: Malik bin Anas). And Ibrahim bin Yaqub Al-Juzajani (d. 259 AH) said: (Malik is among the most established people in him). And Abu Hatim Al-Razi (d. 277 AH) said: (He is the most established of Al-Zuhri's companions). And Al-Nasa'i (d. 303 AH) said: (The most established people in Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri: Malik bin Anas, and Ziyad bin Sa'd Al-Khurasani). See: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal by Imam Ahmad, narration of his son Abdullah (2543), Masa'il Ibn Hani (2128) and (2273), Al-Ma'rifah wa al-Tarikh by Al-Fasawi (2/201), Mashyakhat Al-Nasa'i (77), Su'alat Ibn Al-Junayd (156) and (545), Tarikh Ibn Ma'in by narration of Ibn Tahman (138) and (400), Ma'rifat al-Rijal by Ibn Muhriz (1/120), Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil by Ibn Abi Hatim (8/205), and Sharh 'Ilal Al-Tirmidhi by Ibn Rajab (2/671).

text: Rather, high praise and lofty commendation for him from his sheikh Ibn Shihab was reported in a story that happened to him with him: where Al-Zuhri said to him after narrating to him some ten odd Hadiths: "Does it benefit you that I narrate to you and you do not write?", I said: If you wish, I will repeat them back to you. He said: "Repeat them," so I repeated them back to him, and he said: "Yes, what a repository of knowledge you are!" (1).
foot_note: 1. Ikmal Tahdhib al-Kamal by Ala al-Din Mughlatay (11/31).

book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text: And among the most famous reports in which there was disagreement regarding Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri: The Hadith of Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him; that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever." The disagreement centers on naming his narrator from Usama bin Zaid; is he: "Amr bin Uthman", or "Umar bin Uthman"? Both are sons of Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him: So the companions of Al-Zuhri narrated it naming his narrator "Amr", and Malik differed from them so he named him: "Umar", and he erred in it. And as Ibn Abd al-Barr (d. 463 AH) said: "And Malik is among those whom hardly anyone else is compared to in memorization and precision, but no one is free from error" (1). And the matter in collecting paths and narrations is clarifying the points of agreement and disagreement in them, with highlighting and utilizing the practice of the Imams and their behaviors and methods in narrating it, and looking into the implications of its contexts mentioned in it. And the Hadith of the chapter is among the most famous of what is used as evidence for the care of the critical Imams in clarifying the errors of trustworthy Muhaddiths and correcting them; where we see the succession of Imams and narrators in clarifying the error in naming its narrator, and their stipulation on the correct aspect in it (2).
foot_note:
1. Al-Tamhid: (9/160).
2. Abu Amr Ibn al-Salah (d. 643 AH) mentioned it in his Introduction (p. 88) as an example of the Munkar (denounced) Hadith in which the trustworthy contradicts the Hadith of the trustworthy ones, and I did not see in the speech of those who preceded a description of Malik's narration as Munkar, and what appears to me is that labeling it as contradiction or strangeness is more appropriate and worthy than describing it and including it in the chapters of Munkar, especially according to the terminology established for Munkar among the later scholars.

book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text:
Text of the Hadith: From Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever, nor does a disbeliever inherit from a Muslim." 
Takhrij: 
* This Hadith was narrated by Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri, and it was differed upon him in four ways: 
The First Way: The majority of his companions narrated it: from him, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman (1), from Usama bin Zaid, who said:
foot_note: 1. Amr bin Uthman bin Affan: One of the senior Tabi'in. Mus'ab Al-Zubayri - who is one of the narrators of the chapter's Hadith from Malik - said: (Amr bin Uthman was the eldest of Uthman's children who left offspring) End quote. Ibn Sa'd said: (Amr narrated from his father, and from Usama bin Zaid, and he was trustworthy and had Hadiths). Al-Ijli said: (Madinan Tabi'i trustworthy, one of the senior Tabi'in). Ibn Hibban mentioned him in his Thiqat and said: (He narrates from his father and Usama bin Zaid, Al-Zuhri narrated from Ali bin Hussein from him). He is the son-in-law of Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan through his daughter Ramla, and the Six narrated from him. Note: The statement of Mus'ab Al-Zubayri appeared in Al-Mizzi and Al-Sakhawi, attributed to Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar, and the reason for that is that Al-Zubayr built his book on his uncle's book and added to it. See: Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra by Ibn Sa'd: (7/149), Nasab Quraysh by Mus'ab Al-Zubayri (p. 105), Ma'rifat Al-Thiqat by Al-Ijli: 2/180 (1396), Al-Thiqat by Ibn Hibban (5/168), Tahdhib Al-Kamal (22/155), and Al-Tuhfa Al-Latifa (5/253).

book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text:
The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever." It was narrated from him by [a group] of his companions: (Sufyan bin Uyaynah, Abdul Malik bin Jurayj, Yazid bin Al-Had, Ma'mar bin Rashid Al-Azdi, Uqayl bin Khalid, Yunus bin Yazid, Abdullah bin Budayl, Usama bin Zaid Al-Laythi, Yahya bin Saeed Al-Ansari, Muhammad bin Abi Hafsa, and Zam'a bin Salih).
The Second Way: Malik bin Anas narrated it: and it was differed upon him in three ways:
The First: A group of Malik's companions narrated it, from him, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Umar bin Uthman (1), from Usama bin Zaid, with it, raised (Marfu').
foot_note: 1. Umar bin Uthman bin Affan: One of the Tabi'in, narrated from his father. Ibn Sa'd said: (Al-Zuhri narrated from him, and he had a house in Medina, and he had few Hadiths). Al-Bukhari said: (He heard Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him; Ibrahim bin Umar bin Aban said it, from his father, in his chain there is something). Ibn Abd al-Barr said: (As for the genealogists, they do not differ that Uthman bin Affan had a son named Umar, and he also had a son named Amr). Ibn Hibban mentioned him in Al-Thiqat. Al-Mizzi symbolized Al-Nasa'i's narration for him because it appeared in Malik's Hadith, and I did not find any narration for him other than it. See: Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra by Ibn Sa'd (7/150), Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir by Al-Bukhari (6/178), Al-Jami' Al-Kabir by Al-Tirmidhi (2107), Al-Thiqat by Ibn Hibban (5/146), Al-Tamhid by Ibn Abd al-Barr (9/160), and Tahdhib Al-Kamal by Al-Mizzi (21/458).

The Second: Others narrated it from him, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, with it, raised, like the narration of the majority of Al-Zuhri's companions in the first way; by naming his narrator "Amr" (1).
The Third: Ibn Bukair narrated it from him, with doubt; so he said: "Amr bin Uthman, or Umar bin Uthman".
The Third Way from Al-Zuhri: Abdullah bin Isa narrated it: from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Usama bin Zaid, with it, raised.
The Fourth Way from Al-Zuhri: Hushaym bin Bashir narrated it: with the wording: "People of two different religions do not inherit from each other". It was differed upon him in his chain in two ways:
The First: Mas'ud bin Juwayriyah narrated it, from him, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, and Aban bin Uthman, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, with it. So he added in his chain "Aban bin Uthman".

Appendix: (On the disagreement regarding Al-Awza'i and Ma'mar)
* First: The Hadith of Al-Awza'i, and it was differed upon him in the chapter's Hadith on two ways:
The First Way: Narrated from him, from Al-Zuhri, from Abu Salama, from Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, with the wording: "We are descending tomorrow at Khaif Bani Kinana...".
And the Second Way: Narrated from him, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, where will you stay tomorrow? And that was during the Hajj of the Prophet, peace be upon him. He said: "And has Aqil bin Abi Talib left us any dwelling?", then he said: "A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever, nor a disbeliever from a Muslim", then he said: "We are descending tomorrow at Khaif Bani Kinana, where Quraish swore on disbelief." (1)

* Second: Ma'mar's Hadith, and it was narrated from him briefly and at length:
The First: Restricting to the wording of the group's Hadith: "A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever, nor a disbeliever from a Muslim". It was narrated from him by: (Abdul Razzaq, Abdul A'la bin Abdul A'la, and Yazid bin Zurai'), and the reference to their narration has preceded.
The Second: (Abdul Razzaq) narrated it from Ma'mar with his chain to Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, where will we stay tomorrow? In his Hajj. He said: "And has Aqil left us any dwelling?", then he said: "We are descending tomorrow, God willing, at Khaif Bani Kinana", then he said at that: "A disbeliever does not inherit from a Muslim, nor a Muslim from a disbeliever".

book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text:
Mention of the disagreement reported in its text:
* Ma'mar's Hadith is among what the observers and critics differed upon:
1 - Where Ali bin Al-Madini stated that his saying: "We are descending tomorrow, God willing, at Khaif Bani Kinana", is inserted (Mudraj) by Ma'mar into the Hadith of Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with him, and the correct version is that it is from the Musnad of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him. Ibn Khuzayma and Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi followed him in this. Ali bin Al-Madini said: "The Hadith of Abu Huraira, from the Prophet, peace be upon him: 'Our dwelling tomorrow, God willing, is at Al-Khaif in the forenoon' was narrated by Al-Zuhri, and Al-Zuhri's chain was differed upon: It was narrated by Al-Awza'i, Ibrahim bin Sa'd, Al-Nu'man bin Rashid, and Ibrahim bin Ismail bin Mujammi'; all of them from Al-Zuhri, from Abu Salama, from Abu Huraira (1). Except that Ma'mar inserted it into the Hadith of Ali bin Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid: 'Has Aqil left me any dwelling', so he inserted the speech in it: 'Our dwelling tomorrow'. Muhammad bin Abi Hafsa narrated it from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama, and did not mention in it: 'And our dwelling is at Al-Khaif'" (2).
foot_note:
1. This is the first way of Al-Awza'i's Hadith, and it has preceded.
2. 'Ilal Al-Hadith by Ibn Al-Madini (122), Sahih Ibn Khuzayma (2984), and Al-Fasl lil-Wasl Al-Mudraj fi Al-Matn (75).

text:
The Second Way (From Al-Zuhri): The narration of Malik bin Anas
* Malik bin Anas narrated it, and his companions differed from him in three ways:
The First Way: A group narrated it from him naming his narrator: "Umar bin Uthman", and they are: (Muhammad bin Idris Al-Shafi'i, Khalid bin Mukhlid Al-Qatwani, Abdullah bin Wahb, Mus'ab bin Abdullah Al-Zubayri, Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Shaybani, Abdul Rahman bin Mahdi, Abdullah bin Maslama Al-Qa'nabi, and Ahmad bin Ismail Al-Madani Al-Sahmi).
The Second Way: A group narrated it from him naming his narrator "Amr bin Uthman", and they are: (Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, Abu Mus'ab Al-Zuhri, Zaid bin Al-Hubab, Muawiyah bin Hisham Al-Qassar, Yahya bin Yahya Al-Laythi, Ibrahim bin Tahman, and Abdul Rahman bin Al-Qasim).
The Third Way: Yahya bin Bukair narrated it from Malik, with doubt, so he said in it: "From Amr or Umar bin Uthman".

text:
The First Way (From Malik)
* A group of his companions narrated it from him naming his narrator: "Umar":
It was narrated by: Al-Shafi'i in Al-Umm: (4/75), Ahmad in Al-Musnad: (21813) from Ibn Mahdi - and from his path Al-Ala'i in Bughyat Al-Multamis: (p. 180) - and Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Shaybani in his Muwatta: (728), Abdullah bin Maslama Al-Qa'nabi in his Muwatta (manuscript in Al-Jarahi's handwriting: (A/91)) - and from his path Al-Jawhari in Musnad Al-Muwatta (210), and Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i in Al-Ghilaniyyat: (36) - and Ibn Abi Khaythama in Al-Tarikh (Second Volume): 2/905 (3840) - and from his path Ibn Abd al-Barr in Al-Tamhid (9/162) - from Mus'ab bin Abdullah, and Abu Tahir Al-Mukhallis in Al-Fawa'id Al-Ghara'ib Al-Muntaqah min Al-Mukhallisiyyat: 2/33 (958) - and from his path Ibn Asakir in Al-Tarikh: (46/290) - from Ahmad bin Bujayr, from Ali bin Nufayl, he said: Khalid bin Mukhlid Al-Qatwani told us, and Al-Mahamili in Al-Amali (narration of Ibn Mahdi): (336) - and from his path Salim Al-Razi in Awali Malik: 1/278 (181) - from Ahmad bin Ismail Al-Madani, and Al-Tahawi in Sharh Ma'ani Al-Athar: (3/265) from Yunus - and from his path Al-Jawhari in Musnad Al-Muwatta (210) - from Abdullah bin Wahb -: all of them: (Muhammad bin Idris Al-Shafi'i (1),
foot_note: 1. It appeared in the printed versions of Al-Umm by Al-Shafi'i: "Amr". See: Bulaq 1st edition 1322 AH (4/2), Al-Najjar edition (4/72), and Dar Al-Wafa edition (5/148). - What I deduce is that there is a distortion in the chain followed by the book's editions, and that the correct version in Al-Shafi'i's narration is: "Umar"; for three reasons: First: Al-Shafi'i stated that what is in Malik's narration is: "Umar", and faulted him in it, in what Ibn Abi Hatim and Ibn Khuzayma narrated from Al-Muzani, that he said: I heard Al-Shafi'i say: (Malik misspelled Umar bin Uthman, and it is only: Amr bin Uthman). See: Adab Al-Shafi'i by Ibn Abi Hatim (p. 172), Bayan Khata' Man Akhta' 'ala Al-Shafi'i by Al-Bayhaqi: (p. 202), and Manaqib Al-Shafi'i by Al-Bayhaqi: (1/491). So it is unlikely that he stipulates it, then narrates it from him like the majority's narration on the correct version, while the Imams are in quasi-consensus that what is in Malik's narration is: "Umar". Second: Al-Shafi'i narrated the Hadith about two lines before narrating Malik's Hadith, from the path of Ibn Uyaynah from Al-Zuhri with it, and in it: "Amr", like the rest of the narrations of Al-Zuhri's companions, then he cited Malik's Hadith after it, so perhaps the printer thought they were with one chain so he drew it: "Amr" like its predecessor. Third: That the apparent in Al-Shafi'i's context for Malik's Hadith is only to explain the defect; evidenced by his narrating the Hadith from the path of Ibn Uyaynah and repeating it in Al-Umm in more than four places; unlike Malik's Hadith, he cited it once after Ibn Uyaynah's Hadith in the Book of Inheritance. And Allah knows best.

This is Umar's house, and this is Amr's house), I said to him: So how did he narrate to you? He said: He used to say: Umar End quote. This text is decisive in Ibn Mahdi's narration. Caution: Al-Jawhari narrated Ibn Ma'in's words in Musnad Al-Muwatta (200) - with the same chain as Ibn Al-Muzaffar - and in it: (I said: So how did Ma'n narrate to you? He said: He used to say: Umar) End quote. The editor of Atraf Al-Muwatta by Al-Dani (2/18) Dr. Rida Bu Shama concluded that the mention of Ma'n in Al-Jawhari is an addition and an error, and the correct version of the story is what is mentioned in Ibn Al-Muzaffar in Ghara'ib Malik. Ma'n is Ibn Isa Al-Qazzaz, one of the famous companions of Malik, and even if Ibn Mahdi did not have a direct narration from Malik naming his narrator: (Umar), as reported by Ahmad, Ibn Al-Muzaffar and Al-Ala'i; the possibility would remain that Ibn Mahdi descended in his narration and narrated it from Ma'n - who is one of his peers - correctly, so the result in this difference would be the correctness of what the editor of Al-Atraf went to. And Allah knows best. And it appeared in Atraf Al-Musnad by Ibn Hajar: (111) drawing it in the chain: (Amr), and he cited it in the Hadith of Amr bin Uthman from Usama, and it is an error.

text: • And Malik was followed in it by: Abu Uwais Al-Madani (1): Yahya bin Muhammad bin Yahya Al-Dhuhli said: It was said (to Abu Uwais) (2): They say: Amr bin Uthman? He said: «No, he is Umar bin Uthman, we know better; this is his house», and he mentioned this following the Hadith: «A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever» End quote. I did not find his Hadith with a chain, and Ali bin Al-Madini and Al-Bazzar declared it defective, and stated that the hearing of Abu Uwais and Malik is one from Al-Zuhri (3).
foot_note:
1. He is Abdullah bin Abdullah bin Uwais, Abu Uwais Al-Madani Al-Asbahi, father of Ismail bin Abi Uwais, and son-in-law of Imam Malik through his sister. Ahmad said: (There is no harm in him), or said: (Trustworthy), and said: (Salih), and Ibn Ma'in said: (Weak in Hadith), and Al-Fallas said: (There is weakness in him, and he is among them from the people of truthfulness), and Abu Dawood said: (Salih al-Hadith), and Yaqub bin Shaybah said: (Saduq, and Salih al-Hadith, and to weakness is what he is), and Al-Nasa'i said: (Abu Uwais is weak, and his son Ismail is weaker than him), and said: (Not strong), Muslim and the Four narrated from him. See: Su'alat Abi Dawood: (203), Al-Sunan Al-Kubra by Al-Nasa'i: (7044), Al-Du'afa wa Al-Matrukin by Al-Nasa'i: (674), and Tarikh Madinat Al-Salam: (11/173).
2. Ibn Asakir narrated the story in Tarikh Dimashq: (46/290), and Al-Mizzi in Tahdhib Al-Kamal (22/155). In both sources his naming appeared: (Ibn Abi Uwais!), and the correct is what is established, for he is the one who agreed with Malik, and Ali bin Al-Madini and Al-Bazzar stated his following of Malik, and the Imams' declaration that his hearing from Al-Zuhri is like Malik's hearing appeared, unlike Ibn Abi Uwais, for Abu Hatim Al-Razi reported from him his defecting of his maternal uncle Imam Malik's Hadith, and it has preceded.
3. Ahmad bin Hanbal said: (They claimed that the hearing of Abu Uwais, and the hearing of Malik, were one thing) End quote from Su'alat Abi Dawood to Imam Ahmad: (203), and Al-Barqani reported from Al-Daraqutni that he said: (His hearing with Malik from Al-Zuhri, I said: How is his Hadith from Al-Zuhri? He said: In some of it there is something) End quote from Tarikh Madinat Al-Salam: (11/173), and among those who stated it are Ali bin Al-Madini and Al-Bazzar, and their statement will come in the context of their defecting of Malik's narration, and their stipulation that their hearing from Al-Zuhri is one, does not mean that the error is from Ibn Shihab, rather the correct view - and Allah knows best - is that Abu Uwais followed Malik in the illusion in his chain.

book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text:
The Imams' statements regarding Malik's error in the chain of this Hadith:
A large group of critical Imams stated Malik's error in naming his narrator, and some of them are his peers and companions; yet he remained firm on his saying and said: «This is his house», and did not retract it (1). And following
foot_note: 1. Abu Al-Abbas Al-Dani (d. 532 AH) went far and attributed to Malik a retraction to the correct view in naming his narrator and agreeing with the majority, saying: (Then he retracted later and said: (Amr); he followed the group, thus it was established in Al-Muwatta in the narration of Yahya bin Yahya our companion, and Ibn Al-Qasim, and their hearing is late) End quote from Al-Ima': (2/19). Since Malik's retraction in naming his narrator was not transmitted, and it contradicts the statement of his contemporary Imams emphasizing that in his narration is: (Umar), among them Al-Shafi'i and Ibn Mahdi and others, and if his retraction were established, it would have been transmitted, due to the availability of motives usually in such an issue. What appears from Al-Dani's speech is that it is a deduction from the narrations of Ibn Al-Qasim and Yahya, being late in taking. The succession of Imams in clarifying Malik's error with their lack of transmitting his retraction indicates its negation. And the closer view is that it is an error from Ibn Al-Qasim and Yahya, evidenced by the stipulation of Imams - like Ibn Abi Asim, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Daraqutni, Al-Jawhari, Ibn Abd al-Barr and others - that the correct in Malik's narration is: (Umar). I say: Al-Laythi's narration in this manner is from the omissions of the book (Al-Tatabbu' li-Awham Yahya bin Yahya Al-Laythi fi Riwayatihi lil-Muwatta) issued recently, which was written and edited by the virtuous Sheikh/ Abdul Salam Al-Shuway'ir, may Allah reward him well, and it is among the serious distinguished researches rare in our time.

book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text: 15. Ibn Abd al-Barr (d. 463 AH): He said: «So the companions of Ibn Shihab, other than Malik, say in this Hadith: From Ali bin Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid. And Malik says in it: From Ibn Shihab, from Ali bin Hussein, from Umar bin Uthman, from Usama. Al-Shafi'i and Yahya bin Saeed Al-Qattan stopped him on that, so he said: 'It is Umar', and refused to retract, and said: 'Uthman had a son called: Umar and this is his house'. Malik is hardly compared to anyone else in memorization and precision, but error no one is free from, and the people of Hadith refuse that there be in this chain anything but 'Amr' with Waw. Ali bin Al-Madini said, from Sufyan bin Uyaynah: That it was said to him: Malik says in the Hadith: 'A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever' -: 'Umar bin Uthman', so Sufyan said: I heard it from Al-Zuhri such and such times, and checked it from him, and he did not say except: 'Amr bin Uthman'». Ibn Abd al-Barr said: «Among those who followed Ibn Uyaynah on his saying: 'Amr bin Uthman' -: Ma'mar, Ibn Jurayj, Uqayl, Yunus bin Yazid, Shu'aib bin Abi Hamza, and Al-Awza'i, and the group is more worthy to be submitted to» (1). And he said: «Thus Malik says: 'Umar', and the rest of Ibn Shihab's narrators say: 'Amr bin Uthman'» (2).

1. Al-Tamhid: Morocco ed. (9/160), and Dar Hajar ed. (13/471).
2. Al-Taqassi lima fi Al-Muwatta min Hadith Al-Nabi sallallahu alayhi wa sallam by Ibn Abd al-Barr: (p. 156) Al-Wa'y Al-Islami ed., previously printed under the name (Tajrid Al-Muwatta).

text: 16. Abu Al-Abbas Al-Dani (d. 532 AH): He said: «Malik used to say in the chain of this Hadith: 'Umar bin Uthman', and it is the preserved from him. The rest of Al-Zuhri's narrators said: 'Amr' lightened (without Waw in pronunciation but distinct). Malik was reviewed on it so he said: 'We know him better and this is his house'» End quote (1).

The Second Way (From Malik)
* A group of his companions narrated it from him naming his narrator: "Amr", like the narration of the majority of Al-Zuhri's companions. It was narrated by: Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak in his Musnad: (163) - and from his path Al-Nasa'i in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra (6547), and Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i in Al-Ghilaniyyat: (39) - and Abu Mus'ab Al-Zuhri in his Muwatta: (3061) - and from his path Al-Ala'i in Bughyat Al-Multamis: (p. 181) - and Al-Nasa'i in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra: (6548); from Ahmad bin Sulaiman Al-Ruhawi, from Zaid bin Al-Hubab, H, and in: (6549) from Ahmad bin Sulaiman Al-Ruhawi, from Muawiyah bin Hisham, and Yahya bin Yahya Al-Laythi in his Muwatta: (2/159), and Al-Bukhari in Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir: (6/353) - suspended - from Ibrahim bin Tahman, and Al-Nasa'i in Al-Kubra: (6546) from Muhammad bin Salamah Al-Masri, from Abdul Rahman bin Al-Qasim; and it is in his Muwatta printed with the summary of Abu Al-Hasan Al-Qabisi: (65) = all of them: (Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, Abu Mus'ab Al-Zuhri, Zaid bin Al-Hubab, Muawiyah bin Hisham, Yahya bin Yahya Al-Laythi (1), Ibrahim bin Tahman, and Abdul Rahman bin

Al-Jayyani said: (And the known in the narration of Yahya bin Yahya our companion: Amr... (9/160), and Markaz Hajar ed. (13/471), and it is the established in Al-Muwatta Al-Babi Al-Halabi ed.: (2/159), and Dar Al-Gharb ed. (1475). book_title: Takhrij of the Hadith 'A Muslim does not inherit from a Disbeliever'
text: Narrated it from: Malik, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, with it, raised (1).
foot_note: 1. Amr bin Marzuq differed from them in its text, as Ibn Abd al-Barr narrated in Al-Tamhid: (9/172) from Khalaf bin Qasim, from Ahmad bin Ubaidullah, from Muhammad bin Bakr bin Ziyad bin Al-Ala Al-Mahrani, he said: Amr bin Marzuq told us, Malik informed us, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: (People of two different religions do not inherit from each other) End quote. It is a Shadh (irregular) narration, Ibn Marzuq was unique in its text from Malik, and is not followed, and the rest of Malik's companions are contrary to him. The Imams turning away from it and lack of care for it indicates defectiveness. Ibn Abd al-Barr said: (That is not correct from Malik). As for Amr bin Marzuq, he is Al-Bahili: Ahmad, Abu Hatim, Ibn Sa'd and Ibn Hibban declared him trustworthy. Ahmad said: (Trustworthy, trusted, we searched for what was said about him, and found no basis for it). Ali bin Al-Madini said: (Leave the Hadith of the two Fahds and the two Amrs... and mentioned among them Amr bin Marzuq). Imam Ahmad commented on Ibn Al-Madini's statement saying: (Amr bin Marzuq, a righteous man, I don't know what Ali says). Al-Qawariri transmitted from Al-Qattan that he does not approve of him in Hadith. Ibn Hibban said: (Perhaps he erred). Al-Daraqutni said: (Truthful, many illusions). Al-Bukhari narrated two Hadiths for him: one coupled with another, and the other he cited him as a follower. See: Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra: (9/306), Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil by Ibn Abi Hatim: (6/264), Al-Thiqat by Ibn Hibban: (8/484), Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli: (4/342), Su'alat Al-Hakim to Al-Daraqutni: (423), and Huda Al-Sari by Ibn Hajar: (p. 432).

The companions of this way narrated it from Malik naming him: "Amr" agreeing with the known path narrated by the majority of Al-Zuhri's companions. The correct in Malik's narration is: That it is "Umar bin Uthman", and not "Amr". The companions of this way erred by narrating it from Malik in this manner; for the great ones of his companions narrated it from him correctly by naming his narrator "Umar" - as previously mentioned in the first way - and it is the famous in narration from Malik.

text:
The Third Way (From Malik)
* Yahya bin Bukair narrated it with doubt: where he narrated it in his Muwatta: Istanbul University copy (A/216) and Sulaymaniyah copy (A/94) - and Ala al-Din Mughlatay pointed to his narration in Ikmal Tahdhib Al-Kamal (10/99) - with the wording: Malik told me, from Ibn Shihab, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Amr or Umar bin Uthman bin Affan - Ibn Bukair doubted - from Usama bin Zaid, that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: «A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever».
- It was stated that the doubt in it is from its narrator; who is Yahya bin Bukair.
With the completion of this way ends the listing of differences upon Malik bin Anas. It has become clear: That the correct in his Hadith is by naming his narrator: "Umar". This is the famous in his narration, and that whoever narrated it from him naming his narrator: "Amr" - agreeing with the narration of Al-Zuhri's companions - has differed in it from the correct narrated from Malik through the correct reality of narration.

The Third Way (From Al-Zuhri)
* Abdullah bin Isa (1) narrated it from him, he did not mention "Umar" nor "Amr" in his chain:
It was narrated by: Al-Darimi in his Musnad: (3043) from Muhammad bin Yusuf, Al-Nasa'i in Al-Kubra: (6545) from Ahmad bin Harb, from Qasim bin Yazid, Ibn Al-A'rabi in his Mu'jam: (1383) from Ibn Affan, from Muawiyah bin Hisham, and Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i in Al-Ghilaniyyat: 1/90 (40), and Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat: (5013); both narrated it from Muhammad bin Al-Nadr Al-Azdi, from Muawiyah bin Amr, from Za'idah; the four of them (Muhammad bin Yusuf, Qasim bin Yazid, Muawiyah bin Hisham, and Za'idah) narrated it from Sufyan Al-Thawri, and Al-Nasa'i in Al-Kubra: (6544) from Muhammad bin Bashar, from Muhammad bin Ja'far, and Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i in Al-Ghilaniyyat: 1/90 (41) from Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Yasin, from Nasr bin

Both: (Sufyan Al-Thawri, and Shu'ba bin Al-Hajjaj) = narrated it from Abdullah bin Isa, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Usama bin Zaid, with it, raised. * Explanation of Al-Nasa'i's behavior in his context for this narration:
Among those who narrated Abdullah bin Isa's Hadith: Imam Al-Nasa'i in his Sunan Al-Kubra, and he declared it defective by way of hinting, where he cited his narration at the beginning of the chapter - before the narration of Malik, and the rest of Al-Zuhri's senior companions; with their mentioning of the intermediary in its chain - and he cited his Hadith from the path of two majestic Imams from him, who are (Shu'ba, and Sufyan Al-Thawri) to show through this behavior the following:
1. That the Hadith with this context is his Hadith; and that the responsibility in it is on him, not on those below him (1).

text:
The Fourth Way (From Al-Zuhri)
* Hushaym bin Bashir narrated it with the wording: "People of two different religions do not inherit from each other", and his text contradicted the group's Hadith:
It was differed in Hushaym's Hadith on two ways:
The First Way: Mas'ud bin Juwayriyah narrated it, from Hushaym, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Hussein and Aban bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "People of two different religions do not inherit from each other". Al-Nasa'i narrated it in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra (6555), and said in it following the mention of Aban: "Thus he said", and Al-Mizzi quoted him in Al-Tuhfa saying: "This is an error".
The Second Way: The rest of Hushaym's companions narrated it without mentioning Aban in its chain, with the wording: "People of two religions do not inherit from each other". Their Hadith was narrated by: Al-Tirmidhi (1) in his Jami': (2107), and Al-Nasa'i in Al-Kubra:
foot_note: 1. Al-Tirmidhi narrated it and cited it with the chain of Ibn Uyaynah's Hadith with the wording: (A Muslim does not inherit from a disbeliever). Al-Mizzi said: (Thus Al-Tirmidhi narrated it from Ali bin Hujr, from Hushaym, with the wording of Sufyan bin Uyaynah - he carried the Hadith of one of them on the Hadith of the other - and the preserved from Ali bin Hujr is Al-Nasa'i's wording from him as previously noted) End quote from Tuhfat Al-Ashraf: (113).

(6556); both from Ali bin Hujr, Ahmad bin Hanbal in Al-Ilal - narration of his son Abdullah -: (2202), Saeed bin Mansur in his Sunan: (136), Al-Tahawi in Sharh Ma'ani Al-Athar: (3/266) from Rabi' the Mu'adhin, from Asad bin Musa, Al-Tabarani in Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir: 1/163 (391) from Abu Husayn Al-Qadi, from Yahya Al-Himmani, Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i in Al-Ghilaniyyat: 1/88 (38), and Ibn Abd al-Barr in Al-Tamhid: (9/171) from Abdul Warith bin Sufyan, from Qasim bin Asbagh; both (Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i, and Qasim bin Asbagh) narrated it from Muhammad bin Ismail Al-Tirmidhi, from Al-Hasan bin Sawwar, H, and Abu Bakr Al-Shafi'i in Al-Ghilaniyyat: 1/88 (38) from Abu Qabisa bin Al-Qa'qa', from Ibrahim bin Abdullah = all of them: (Ali bin Hujr, Saeed bin Mansur, Asad bin Musa, Yahya Al-Himmani, Ahmad bin Hanbal, Al-Hasan bin Sawwar, and Ibrahim bin Abdullah) = narrated it from: Hushaym bin Bashir, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "People of two religions do not inherit from each other".
It is a Munkar (denounced) Hadith, Hushaym bin Bashir was alone in it, and he contradicted the rest of Al-Zuhri's companions in its text and was not followed in it. He is famous for Tadlis (concealing defects in the chain) (1), and he did not explicitly state hearing in it, and he concealed it from
foot_note: 1. Ahmad bin Hanbal said: (He used to practice Tadlis wildly, and perhaps he would bring the letter he did not hear, so he mentions it in another Hadith, if the speech is cut off he connects it), and Muhanna said: I asked Abu Abdullah about Hushaym so he said: (Trustworthy if he does not practice Tadlis), I said to him: Is Tadlis a defect? He said: (Yes) End quote. Ibn Sa'd said: (Whatever he said in his Hadith: 'Akhbarana' is a proof, and whatever he did not say in it: 'Akhbarana' is nothing). Rather the stipulation came from Hushaym himself, so Abdullah bin Ahmad said: Some of our companions told me, saying: Hushaym said: (If I say to you: 'Haddathana', and 'Akhbarana', then hold on to it with your hands). Those who stated he is among the Mudallisin - other than Imam Ahmad and Ibn Sa'd - include: Ibn Hibban, Al-Ijli, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Daraqutni, Ibn Adi and Al-Khalili. text:
Explanation of Al-Nasa'i's behavior in his context for Hushaym's Hadith (1)
Al-Nasa'i narrated in Al-Kubra both ways reported from Hushaym bin Bashir, and first clarified the investigation of the correct from the reality of narration from Hushaym, and declared Mas'ud bin Juwayriyah's narration from Hushaym mentioning Aban in his chain as defective, saying: «This is an error». Then he narrated the correct way from Hushaym in this Hadith, so he narrated it from the path of Ali bin Hujr - which a group of Hushaym's companions agreed with him on - he said: Hushaym informed us, from Al-Zuhri, from Ali bin Al-Hussein, from Amr bin Uthman, from Usama bin Zaid, with it. Then he clarified his uniqueness in its text, and his contradiction to the rest of Al-Zuhri's companions.
With Hushaym's Hadith ends the speech on the faces of difference on Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri in the chapter's Hadith. It has become clear from what preceded; that the correct of them is the first way, which the majority of his companions narrated from him correctly in its text and chain. And Allah knows best, and may Allah send blessings and peace and blessings upon our Prophet Muhammad and upon his family and companions all.
foot_note: 1. Of the precision of Al-Nasa'i's work in his Sunan Al-Kubra is that he investigates the narrator's error how it was narrated from him! Then he speaks about his narration afterwards and explains its contradiction to the Hadith of the trustworthy established ones as you see clearly in the faces of difference from Malik, and in the difference on Hushaym in this way.
